statement:
[ **-**]{} Let $X$ be an inner product space (over $\mathbb{R}$ or
$\mathbb{C}$) and $x, y \in X$ two orthogonal vectors. Then
$$\|x+y\|^2 = \|x\|^2 + \|y\|^2.$$

[**Proof :**]{} As $x \perp y$ one has $\langle x, y \rangle = 0$. Then
$$\begin{aligned}
\|x+y\|^2 & = & \langle x+y, x+y \rangle \\
& = & \langle x, x \rangle + \langle x, y \rangle + \langle y, x \rangle + \langle y, y \rangle \\
& = & \|x\|^2 + \langle x, y \rangle + \overline{\langle x, y \rangle} +\|y\|^2 \\
& = & \|x\|^2 + \|y\|^2 \qquad\qquad\qquad\quad \square\end{aligned}$$

$Remark -$ This theorem is valid (with the same proof) for spaces with a
semi-definite inner product.
names: Pythagorean theorem in inner product spaces
Pythagoras theorem in inner product spaces
